title: 103_s1123
content: The "Reforestation Tax Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. It includes a partial inflation adjustment for timber in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Reforestation Tax Act of 1993" allows taxpayers with qualified timber gain to deduct a percentage of the gain from their gross income. Qualified timber gain is the lesser of net capital gain or net capital gain from timber. The qualified percentage is determined by multiplying 3 percent by the number of years the taxpayer held the timber. In the case of estates or trusts, similar provisions apply. In the case of an estate or trust, the deduction for gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets is computed by excluding the portion includible by income beneficiaries as gain derived from the sale or exchange of capital assets. Coordination with existing limitations includes amendments to the maximum capital gains rate and alternative tax for corporations. The tax code is amended to include a deduction for qualified timber gain, with a partial inflation adjustment. This deduction is added to the definition of adjusted gross income. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections. The tax code is amended to include a deduction for qualified timber gain with a partial inflation adjustment, effective for sales or exchanges after December 31, 1992. The tax code amendment allows for a deduction for qualified timber gain with a partial inflation adjustment, effective for sales or exchanges after December 31, 1992. Treasury regulations exempt closely held timber activities with less than 100 hours of management annually. Closely held activities are defined as those with 80% ownership held by 5 or fewer individuals or family members. Limited partnerships are not considered closely held activities. The term "timber activity" includes planting, cultivating, caring, cutting, or preparing trees for market, excluding milling. The amendments in this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1992. SEC. 4. AMORTIZATION OF REFORESTATION EXPENDITURES AND REFORESTATION TAX CREDIT. Increase in Maximum Amortizable Amount under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to $20,000 ($10,000 inflation adjustment) for taxable years beginning after 1993. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increases the maximum amortizable amount to $20,000 for taxable years after 1993. Additionally, there is a decrease in the amortization period for reforestation credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increases the maximum amortizable amount to $20,000 for taxable years after 1993 and decreases the amortization period from 84 months to 60 months. Trusts are now eligible for the deduction and credit. The effective date for these changes is specified. The amendments made by this section apply to additions to capital account and the reforestation credit under section 48(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for property acquired after December 31, 1992.
